Award.AwardTitle: DeafTEC: Technological Education Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID), one of the eight colleges of the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), is developing and implementing the ATE Center of Excellence, DeafTEC: Technological Education Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students. DeafTEC serves as a resource for high schools and community colleges that educate deaf and hard-of-hearing (deaf/hh) students in STEM-related programs and for employers hiring deaf/hh individuals. The Center outcomes include: (1) a comprehensive website providing a clearinghouse for information related to technical education and technician careers for deaf/hh students, including career awareness materials, teaching strategies for improving student access to learning, developmental math and English curricula, and information for employers to help them provide a more accessible workplace; and (2) a model within three targeted regions of the country, California, Florida, and Texas, that creates partnerships among high schools, community colleges, and industry to improve access to technological education and employment for deaf/hh students. The goal is to successfully integrate more deaf/hh individuals into the workplace in highly skilled technician jobs where these individuals are currently underrepresented and underutilized.

The Center is impacting the knowledge and attitudes of high school teachers, community college faculty, employers, and the deaf/hh students themselves in terms of the educational and employment opportunities and options available to these students. DeafTec is providing professional development experiences in STEM subjects and in pedagogy that provides greater access to learning for deaf/hh students, as well as all students in the classroom including those with language difficulties. Finally, it is establishing, expanding, or improving pathways for deaf/hh students to transition from high school to college in several STEM areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DeafTEC: Technological Center for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students is an NSF-funded Advanced Technological Education National Center of Excellence established in 2011 at the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, a college of the Rochester Institute of Technology. The goal of DeafTEC is to successfully integrate more deaf and hard-of-hearing individuals (deaf/hh) into the workplace in highly skilled STEM technician jobs where they are currently underrepresented and underutilized.

To accomplish that goal, DeafTEC is providing deaf/hh students and employees, as well as their teachers, counselors, employers, and co-workers, with resources that will help these deaf/hh individuals succeed both in the classroom and on the job. For the nation’s high-tech employers, integrating more deaf/hh employees into their companies creates a more diverse workforce, and encourages respect of individuals currently underrepresented in these highly technical fields. For deaf/hh individuals, careers in STEM provide a higher level of income that they do not find in non-STEM careers.

To fulfill these objectives, DeafTEC has established:

(1) A regional partnership model to cooperatively promote best practices in educating and employing deaf/hh individuals

(2) A comprehensive website that provides deaf/hh students, their parents, teachers, and employers with a wide range of resources related to technical education and technician careers

(3) An expanded national STEM dual credit program, Project Fast Forward

Regional Partnership Model

The goal of the DeafTEC partnership model is to build a mutually supportive professional community in selected regions of the country to improve access to technological education and employment for deaf/hh students. DeafTEC established this train-the-trainer partnership model by selecting one high school, one community college, and one or more employers within Florida, Texas, and California, the three states that have the largest deaf/hh populations. Personnel from each regional partner were trained to offer DeafTEC workshops on best teaching practices, instructional materials and strategies for helping deaf/hh students develop skills in English and math, and strategies for employers to successfully integrate deaf/hh individuals into the workplace. During this funding period, DeafTEC partners offered 100 workshops to a total of 1,608 educators and employers in Florida, Texas, and California. This successful regional partnership model could be replicated in other regions as well as with other groups of underserved students.

DeafTEC Website – www.deaftec.org

The DeafTEC website serves as a national resource on technical education and technician careers for deaf/hh students, their parents, teachers, and future employers. With its emphasis on Universal Design for Instruction and materials and strategies for teaching math and English, DeafTEC’s resources benefit not only deaf/hh students, but all students, particularly those with language difficulties. Website resources include:

  • STEM awareness materials (www.deaftec.org/stem-careers) featuring professional videos of deaf/hh STEM professionals and information on careers in Information Technology, Engineering/Manufacturing and Lab Science.
  • Employer resources (www.deaftec.org/employers) to help employers attract and hire deaf/hh employees, and successfully integrate them into the workplace.
  • Best practices in teaching (www.deaftec.org/classact) that provides extensive resources on effective strategies for teaching deaf/hh students, particularly in mainstreamed settings, with an emphasis on Universal Design for Instruction.
  • English resources (www.deaftec.org/resources/english), containing a variety of resources for using a Writing in the Disciplines approach to improving student writing and helping students "write to learn."
  • Math resources (www.deaftec.org/resources/math/self-instruction) featuring over 60 signed, captioned, and voiced math videos making the learning of math more accessible to deaf/hh students as well as other students who struggle with math.
  • A STEM sign language video dictionary currently displaying accurate signs for technical vocabulary as well as singed definitions and usage for three STEM disciplines: Information Technology, Lab Sciences, and Mathematics. The project is supported in part with a gift from The Dow Chemical Company.

Project Fast Forward

Through an earlier NSF grant (DUE #060276), this national STEM dual credit program allowed students to take NTID college-level courses in the area of Information Technology while they were still in high school. The grant included professional development for high school teachers and counselors, and the opportunity for teachers to teach the courses in their own high schools. DeafTEC included expanding Project Fast Forward in its set of initiatives, and added the disciplines of Engineering/Manufacturing, Graphic Arts, and Lab Science. Under DeafTEC funding, Project Fast Forward has:

  • Doubled the number partner high schools from 14 schools in 8 states to 30 schools in 15 states 
  • Offered professional development to 11 high school counselors
  • Offered professional development to 48 high school teachers (34 new to the program and 15 returning)
  • Increased STEM dual credit course offerings from 4 to 10
  • Offered 92 STEM dual credit course sections in our partner high schools
  • Registered 382 students in STEM dual credit courses
  • Awarded 726 college credits to 242 students who passed STEM dual credit courses
